timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal of county of Blamont asks prévôt and court at Blamont to take evidence against Jeanne, suspected of causing deaths and illnesses of people and animals. May arrest her if she seems likely to flee, as is rumoured.

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Informations preparatoires begin. Note that she had been made prisoner that day. 22 witnesses examined over several days.

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for interrogation and confrontations

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: First interrogation without torture. She denied charges but admitted to various quarrels.

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses. She admitted being called witch but denied all charges of witchcraft.

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for question ordinaire et extraordinaire

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Change de Nancy agrees to torture

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: First torture session. Given thumbscrews on hands and feet, then racked, but would confess nothing. Judges noted she was strong and robust. Only then was she shaved all over. Next day was feast day of St Mansuy, so further questioning delayed.

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Second torture session. Racked again, then given tortillons on right arm. Began to confess. Admitted being witch for 2 years, killing horses and child, attending sabbat. Later retracted false accusations against two people she had named.

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Procureur fiscal asks for death sentence

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence, subject to repetition of confessions. Also note that torture should not be repeated without advice being sought.

timeline.subject: Jeanne Mercier
timeline.details: Blamont court records that she had killed herself in prison, by throwing herself down from top of room where she was held; body is to be dragged through town on a sledge then burned.

accomplices_named.name: Anne femme Claude Jean Clerc
accomplices_named.context: Named under torture as accomplice at sabbat, said she was going to kill child of Demenge Bageat. Jeanne later retracted this accusation, saying charge was false because Anne was responsible for her imprisonment.

accomplices_named.name: Jean Didier Aulbry
accomplices_named.context: Named under torture as accomplice at sabbat. Jeanne later retracted this accusation.

prior_accusations.context: Father reputed witch for 15 years. Had left to become herdsman at Amenoncourt after being accused of killing animals. After Jeanne's arrest, he fled from village of Montreux where he was living.

economic_context.details: Margueritte femme Demenge Bugeat testified that her husband had lent Jeanne's husband 40 francs, and he then complained he was being overcharged for interest. A horse then sickened and died, which she suspected might also have been Jeanne's witchcraft. Jeanne's husband kept the pigs of the village at one point, and later kept cattle, positions that were taken over by others, causing resentment and threats.

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial with 22 witnesses, extensive testimony about quarrels and harms, two torture sessions, false denunciations later retracted, and tragic ending by suicide. The pattern of harm-after-quarrel is exceptionally clear. Jeanne showed significant resistance and defiance throughout. Her father's reputation and flight after her arrest is notable. The confession under torture follows leading questions and includes conventional sabbat elements. The suicide prevented execution and repetition of confession required by appeals court.
